a month by signing up at https://dashlane.com/hai.

The Capitol of the United States, a country
in North America, has a basement.

This basement is of course where the US government
keeps the original Elon Musk, the chemtrail

factory, and covfefe but what you might not
know is that down here is something else—this:
the United States Capitol subway system.

Now, the US capitol is believed to be here
in Washington, DC which has a subway system.

It’s known for breaking down, catching on
fire, and running less frequently than Chris

Christie but this is an entirely different,
unconnected system that’s exclusively for
the use of those working at the US Capitol.

This subway is used to transport the lawmakers
of the US to destinations about 1,000 feet

away and as much as I’d like to make fun
of powerful people refusing to walk such a

short distance, this subway’s existence
actually sort of makes sense.
Let me explain.
The US capitol is big but not big enough.

It was big enough when it opened in 1800 since
there were 137 congresspeople and their staff

were themselves but by 1900 when there were
447 congresspeople and they were starting

to get staffs, the Capitol was getting too
small.

You see, why that is is because more people
take up more space.

Today’s Congress is made up of 535 lawmakers
who each have an average of 45 staff members.

Now, not every congressional staffer works
in DC, many work back in the district that

the congressperson represents, but still,
with 535 lawmakers and dozens of staffers

each, they just can’t all fit in the US
capitol.

It’s 1.5 million square feet which, granted,
is large but the nearby DC convention center,

for example, is 60% larger and the largest
building in the world, the New Century Global

Center in Chengdu, China, as a totally arbitrary
comparison, has as much floor space as 13
US Capitols.

Since Congress literally runs the country,
they got to vote 100 years ago on how to deal

with the overcrowding of the Capitol and this
subway system was what finally convinced them

to go ahead with relocating their offices
to here—the new Congressional office buildings.

There’s the Russel, Dirksen, and Hart Senate
office buildings and Cannon, Longworth, and

Rayburn House office buildings and most of
them are connected to the Capitol by this
aforementioned subway.

Part of why this exists is because members
of Congress are actually under no obligation
to show up to votes.

They could hypothetically get elected, do
nothing, and still earn their $174,000 yearly
salary.

Of course this wouldn’t do wonders for their
re-election chances but they could still do
it.

In summary, there are more rules to being
the guy who runs the soft serve machine at

McDonalds than being the guy who runs the
war machine of the United States and coincidently,
both of these are almost always dysfunctional.

In one day the US Congress can have dozens
of votes many of them important, but many

of them also mundane so one wants to be sure
it’s as easy as possible for congresspeople

to get from their offices to the voting floor
so they don’t play hooky.

If no subway or underground passage existed,
they would have to exit their building, cross

busy streets, and re-clear security at the
Capitol which would waste heaps of time and
expose them to the real world.

Using the subway, congressmen and women can
go door to door from their offices to the

voting floor in under five minutes and so
it increases congressional attendance.

Now, as quick review for non-Americans, the
US Congress is made up of two bodies—the

House and the Senate—and each of them actually
has their own separate subway system going
to their own separate office buildings.

For the Senate there are two different lines—one
that goes to the Russel Office Building and

one that stops at both the Dirksen and Hart
buildings—and then on the House side there
is just one line down to the Rayburn building.

If you’re in the Cannon or Longworth buildings,
though, you’re out of luck.
There are no subways.
Only plain old vanilla tunnels.

Lobbyists and journalists love this subway
system as it funnels all the powerful people

they want to talk to through one choke point
so there are supposedly often people waiting
around at the different ends.

Still though, not everyone uses DC’s little
subway.

At least one Republican senator forbade his
staff from using it out of protest for government

waste while others, including during her terms
Hillary Clinton, have been know to skip the
ride and walk instead for exercise.

All the more senior members of Congress have
their own mini offices in the Capitol known

as “hideaways,” but to get to their main
headquarters, that’s what this subway is
for.

So, let’s say you’re a US politician and
you have your own email account, you’re

not supposed to but you do, and you want to
make sure it’s not hacked by say…
Russians.

The best way for you to do that would probably
be to use Dashlane because Dashlane is no
longer just the password manager it once was.

It’s now a holistic online identity protection
platform.

It monitors the dark web to see if your email
or passwords are up for sale, it gives you
